abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Earthquake Schools
            Rehabilitation Project for Nepal was satisfactory. The
            project has achieved most of its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development has been partially successful,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, while the project achieved
            its physical targets due in large measure to its basic and
            simple formulation, the introduction of design variants to
            deal more effectively with geographic differences in climate
            and class size might have improved the final product.
            Second, if regular government employees are not motivated or
            capable of undertaking complex temporary assignments
            involving protracted field work, it is possible to
            successfully utilize competent, contracted staff, supported
            by a decentralized management structure. Third, while
            community participation is critical in an activity such as
            school construction in Nepal, it is important to avoid
            applying uniform expectations across all groups, since not
            all communities may be able or sufficiently interested in
            participation. Finally, when the Government is reluctant to
            use credit resources for technical assistance, an IDA
            project is likely to perform better when complemented by a
            grant component.

Nepal - Earthquake Emergency Schools
            Rehabilitation Project : Credit 2047 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Nepal - Earthquake Emergency
            Schools Rehabilitation Project : Credit 2047 - Credit
            Agreement - Conformed

repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Earthquake Emergency Schools
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Earthquake Schools Rehabilitation
            Project will assist the Government of Nepal with the
            reconstruction of about 2,000 destroyed or seriously damaged
            schools and the repair of a further 350 earthquake affected
            schools in Eastern and Central Nepal. It will also provide
            technical assistance to the Government for the engineering
            design of earthquake resistance measures in the school
            buildings, for management assistance and for auditing and
            evaluation. The credit will finance: (i) the provision of
            basic school structures comprising a roof, permanent floor
            and sill height perimeter walls; (ii) building elements not
            readily available in communities plus skilled labor and
            technical supervision for the construction; (iii) equipment
            and supplies for the field staff; (iv) vehicles for
            transportation and selected staff; (v) consultant services;
            and (vi) operating costs associated with project
            administration. The credit will also finance an estimated 25
            percent of the cost of transporting construction materials
            from designated depots to building sites and of construction
            work undertaken by communities. Community inputs will be in
            the form of labor for porterage, for stockpiling of locally
            available materials and for labor during construction.
